Award.AwardTitle: CoMETS: Critical Mass of Engineering Technology Scholars

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Participation in the development of innovative technologies requires diverse perspectives in order to quickly adapt to emerging technologies. This scholarship project at the Rochester Institute of Technology is designed to increase the diversity in Engineering Technology by addressing factors that contribute to the underrepresentation of women and minorities in these majors. The scholars in this program complete a course designed to enhance study skills, encourage graduate studies, emphasize workforce readiness, and build a community of scholars. Scholars are linked with mentors from both academia and industry. Scholarships are offered to academically talented and economically disadvantaged freshman and third year transfer students. One of the goals of this project is to demonstrate that the presence of a critical mass of underrepresented groups can aid in recruitment and retention of students in STEM disciplines. The project includes outreach activities led by the scholars that encourage K-12 students to consider STEM careers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Critical Mass of Engineering Technology Scholars (CoMETS) program was to build a critical mass of female scholars in Engineering at the Rochester Institute of Technology by recruiting, retaining, and graduating 44 additional female students to these programs.  The project demonstrated that the presence of a critical mass of underrepresented groups could aid in recruitment and retention of students in STEM disciplines. The objectives of the COMETS program were to:

  • Engage scholars in the Women in Technology community through participation in professional development workshops, socials, mentoring, and outreach events.
  • Effectively prepare the scholars for the workforce or graduate school.
  • Reinforce the students’ decision to major in Engineering Technology.
  • Perform regular and thorough assessment of the CoMETS program. 
  • Identify scholars struggling academically and provide proactive academic support. 

The COMETS project strategies to achieve the objectives include academic, social support and professional skills development provided by the Women in Technology program in the college. Faculty mentors were assigned to the scholars. Additionally, assistance was available to the scholars by the existing RIT support network: a well-established, substantial network of support services encompassing areas ranging from academic support centers to the Women’s Center to health and wellness programming.

The first CoMETS scholarships were awarded in 2012.  Scholarships were offered to academically talented and economically disadvantaged freshman and third year transfer students. Each scholar received scholarship support of $6,000-10,000 per academic year. Fifty-one scholars participated in this S-STEM program. Although, retention of scholars in the CoMETS program was 72%, many of the scholars who left (7 out of 14) continued to stay in STEM programs. All but four remained at RIT. We feel the CoMETS program was instrumental in helping students understand and make more informed decisions on their academic major and career goals. Additionally, retention improved every year with targeted academic support, peer mentoring, and focusing scholar selection on students with stronger academic qualifications.

The CoMETS project played a role in increasing the representation of women in the ET programs at RIT.  Prior to the project, women represented ~9 % of enrollment.  In 2016, this had increased 13 % (a 44 % increase).

The evaluation of the CoMETS program identified three themes that were important for the success of the scholars:  relatedness, competence, and autonomy, which are the foundations for intrinsic motivation based on Self-Determination Theory.

Intellectual Merit: This scholarship project was designed to increase the diversity in Engineering Technology by addressing factors that contribute to the underrepresentation of women and minorities in these majors. By addressing factors that support the development of relatedness, competence, and autonomy; the CoMETS program made a meaningful and lasting impact on the chronic problem of inclusion of women in engineering technology disciplines and workforce.

Broader Impacts: Through broad dissemination efforts, this project has aided in diversifying the STEM workforce by demonstrating best practices for the development and effectiveness of a student support network that directly addresses the psychological needs for autonomy, competence and relatedness. This research-based framework can continuously aid in recruitment and retention of members of underrepresented students in STEM disciplines. The project includes outreach activities to encourage K-12 students to consider STEM careers.
